<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_dma_map(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i, j;
	void *vaddr_sg_lo, *vaddr_sg_hi, *vaddr_lo, *vaddr_hi;
	struct metal_io_region *io;

	(void)lbus;
	(void)dir;

	/* Check if the the input virt address is MMIO address */
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		vaddr_sg_lo = sg_in[i].virt;
		vaddr_sg_hi = vaddr_sg_lo + sg_in[i].len;
		for (j = 0, io = ldev->device.regions;
		     j < (int)ldev->device.num_regions; j++, io++) {
			vaddr_lo = io->virt;
			vaddr_hi = vaddr_lo + io->size;
			if (vaddr_sg_lo >= vaddr_lo &&
			    vaddr_sg_hi <= vaddr_hi) {
				break;
			}
		}
		if (j == (int)ldev->device.num_regions) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "%s,%s: input address isn't MMIO addr: 0x%x,%d.\n",
			__func__, ldev->dev_name, vaddr_sg_lo, sg_in[i].len);
			return -EINVAL;
		}
	}
	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (sg_out != sg_in)
	memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
explanation: Rule 21.17 concerns use of functions from <string.h>. The only such function in this function is memcpy, so only the memcpy call (and its guarding condition / size expression) needs investigation. The memcpy size argument uses nents_in (an int) multiplied by sizeof(struct metal_sg) which can provoke out-of-bounds access (or integer-to-size_t conversion issues, or negative nents_in resulting in a very large size) and memcpy is used even when sg_out != sg_in (overlap is possible even if pointers differ). Other code fragments (pointer arithmetic to compute vaddr_sg_hi and vaddr_hi, the loop that checks regions, the metal_log call, variable declarations, and comparisons) do not invoke any <string.h> routines and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 and need not be investigated for this rule.
